body: I tried it and checked the good. Removing only a couple of lines looks kind of suspicious but I found that it works good. LGTM

for:

1.  I think that should be mentioned in the property documentation explicitly
2.  I think that it is fine to do this as a follow on
3.  Maybe we can log the matching pattern or something to start?  At some debug level
Also, should it be an error if any of the grok patterns do not produce something matching the schema during validation?

Thanks for the reply! The current documentation for the `STRING_FIELDS_FROM_GROK_EXPRESSION` strategy notes that the fields will be derived from the Grok Expression, so I will update it to mention that this includes fields from all configured expressions.

As far as the matching pattern, logging the match could be verbose given the potential volume of information processed. Although this might make sense at the trace level, it could still result in hundreds or thousands of log per FlowFile. It seems better to avoid logging for now, and consider a separate task to optionally include the matching pattern index on the record.

Given the different schema strategies and the ability to configure different behavior when there are no matching expressions, it does not seem like it should be an error if the patterns do not produce something matching the schema.
I updated the schema strategy @ottobackwards, please let me know if you have any additional feedback.
I will review/test
Tested this out with a secure 3 node cluster and a secure external ZK. Looks good to me, will merge!

Thank you @simonbence for reviewing this PR. While working on another XMLReader-related improvement, I found a better solution to this problem than my previous solution. I force-pushed my modifications to this branch. I managed to eliminate the hidden dependency between XMLRecordSource and XMLRecordReader by not using the hard-coded "value" field.

@MikeThomsen, I created a separate pull request #5929 upgrading the Microsoft Azure dependencies in `nifi-property-protection-azure` using the bill of materials dependency. Based on some initial testing, that seems to work better with the latest version of Jackson, without having to include the `woodstox-core` dependency. Upgrading the Microsoft Azure dependencies for that module might be a helpful prerequisite to this pull request updating Jackson.

I noticed that only a few of the build options for SNMP are utilized:

https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/b019a9191f1c83bc7f547dc02c1b679b8936acee/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/processors/ListenTrapSNMP.java#L110-L115

But there are many other configuration settings including host which seems foundational:

https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/b019a9191f1c83bc7f547dc02c1b679b8936acee/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/configuration/SNMPConfiguration.java#L119-L133

I guess this question is two fold:

1. How were the other parameters missed for snmp traps? Hosts is definitely needed.
2. How are others using ListenTrapSNMP? Are they actually using it without specifying a host?

Hi,

Can you please send an email to the NiFi mailing list with further questions? https://nifi.apache.org/mailing_lists.html

  1.  The parameters weren't missed, ListenTrapSNMP has exactly this many parameters. The ListenTrap processor runs on the same host where the NiFi instance does. How would you like to use it?
  3.  For the time being that's the only way.


You can check the processor "usage" and the additional details on the NiFi UI for v3 authentication for instance.

Regards,
Lehel Boér

https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/b019a9191f1c83bc7f547dc02c1b679b8936acee/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/processors/ListenTrapSNMP.java#L110-L115

But there are many other configuration settings including host which seems foundational:

https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/b019a9191f1c83bc7f547dc02c1b679b8936acee/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/configuration/SNMPConfiguration.java#L119-L133

I guess this question is two fold:

  2.  How are others using ListenTrapSNMP? Are they actually using it without specifying a host?

@exceptionfactory any parts you want to salvage from this PR then?

> @exceptionfactory any parts you want to salvage from this PR then?

Thanks @MikeThomsen, with PR #5927 upgrading Apache POI to 5.2.2, I don't think any of the other changes are necessary. The work outlined in [NIFI-9849](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-9849) will remove the the `spring-security-saml2-core` dependency entirely, so it does not seem that the direct reference to `xmlsec` will be necessary after that work is completed.

For example, the GetSNMP has a field for hostname and I can validate it:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5004148/161803747-e930f37c-f580-4829-82a9-cbb49c4130cc.png)

But with ListenTrapSNMP I am unable to specify a hostname and it does not validate:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5004148/161803886-053055ef-7853-4594-b24a-5cba09cd35e6.png)

My SNMP is running on localhost anyway, so I am wondering how others use ListenTrapSNMP and validate its connection? 

Update: It looks like adding in a Users File Path may be a JSON which can allow for hostnames to be specified, however I am not picking up trap events even with the following:
```.json
{
  "agentAddress" : {
    "hostname" : "localhost",
    "port" : 2161,
    "ipProtocol" : "udp"
  },
  "trapAddress" : {
    "hostname" : "localhost",
    "port" : 2162,
    "ipProtocol" : "udp",
    "securityName" : "unsec"
  },
  "user" : {
    "name" : "unsec"
  }
}
```

Those same values work when I use it manually. 
Is there an example of this Users File somewhere I can base my work off of? I don't see it in the docs: https://nifi.apache.org/docs/nifi-docs/components/org.apache.nifi/nifi-snmp-nar/1.16.0/org.apache.nifi.snmp.processors.ListenTrapSNMP/index.html

Update-2:
I found an example of a conf file here: https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/bd7536b257907d9012084c27dc5cc3595e5dba3d/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/test/resources/users.json#L1-L16

However I also see I am limited to the following parameters in the json:
```
UnrecognizedPropertyException: Unrecognized field "securityLevel" (class org.apache.nifi.snmp.dto.UserDetails), not marked as ignorable (5 known properties: "authProtocol", "privPassphrase", "authPassphrase", "securityName", "privProtocol"])
```

So I am back to square 1. How do I tell NiFi what the hostname is for the source of the TRAP events? (Also, I am equally puzzled how suppling a hostname is not foundational to connecting to an SNMP source - even GetSNMP wants a hostname. How do others use this module if they don't supply a hostname. I am thinking I am missing something fundamental here...)

I noticed in the tests, the runner sets the hostname properties:
https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/bd7536b257907d9012084c27dc5cc3595e5dba3d/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/test/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/helper/testrunners/SNMPV3TestRunnerFactory.java#L79-L83 So it looks like in the test realm hostnames are covered. When running live, it's not as clear. 

Update-3:

I am experimenting with an update: https://github.com/esend7881/nifi/commit/007c24adbc401ec5bf8fe121c07ea19263e645f2 (If this link is dead, it could be that I amended it before I could update this. Here is a [link to my branch commits](https://github.com/esend7881/nifi/commits/hotfix/nifi-1.16.0/listentrapsnmp-hostname).)
Re-testing right now (with change adding '.' back in).
@exceptionfactory rebased and ready for review

@esend7881 - I think there is a confusion here.

- GetSNMP/SetSNMP processors are meant to be used for interacting with an external SNMP server to retrieve/set values for given OIDs.
- ListenSNMPTrap does not connect to anything. It's starting a listener on the NiFi node so that external systems can send SNMP traps to the NiFi node. NiFi is playing the role of an SNMP server in some ways.

There is no way to specify the host for ListenSNMPTrap simply because it's a listener processor. It's just like ListenHTTP or ListenTCP processors.

Update:
Okay I think I see what is wrong here. In short, I have an unsecured SNMP user set up, but it looks like when using an unsecured user, the SnmpUtils class throws a runtime exception:
```
2022-04-06 12:43:57,060 WARN [Timer-Driven Process Thread-6] o.a.n.controller.tasks.ConnectableTask Administratively Yielding ListenTrapSNMP[id=001d380e-0180-1000-f108-ee3dda6b5dff] due to uncaught Exception: org.apache.nifi.snmp.exception.InvalidAuthProtocolException: Invalid authentication protocol provided.
org.apache.nifi.snmp.exception.InvalidAuthProtocolException: Invalid authentication protocol provided.
	at org.apache.nifi.snmp.utils.SNMPUtils.getAuth(SNMPUtils.java:166)
	at org.apache.nifi.snmp.operations.SNMPTrapReceiverHandler.convertToUsmUser(SNMPTrapReceiverHandler.java:113)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$3$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:195)
```

https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/b019a9191f1c83bc7f547dc02c1b679b8936acee/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/utils/SNMPUtils.java#L162-L167

Where my user conf file was:
```.json
[
  {
    "securityName":"unsec"
  }
]
```

But when I changed it to this, it works:
```.json
[
  {
    "securityName":"cdl_agent",
    "authProtocol":"SHA",
    "authPassphrase":"Password123",
    "privProtocol":"AES128",
    "privPassphrase":"Password123"
  }
]
```

I may look into finding a way around that RuntimeException for the unsecured username, but as of now, I'll move forward knowing I need to setup the authProtocol and such

Thanks for the contribution @gresockj. Can you provide some additional details on how the change improves performance? It seems like there is more work involved in unpacking to a temporary directory and moving, as opposed to just unpacking directly to the working directory. This impacts more than Stateless, so it would be helpful to understand the implications for all deployment form-factors.
The maven build was successful on Windows. Appears to just be hung up on the completion-cleanup task. Going to merge now.

> Can you provide some additional details on how the change improves performance?

Sure -- in some use cases if the unpacking is interrupted, the working directory may be incomplete.  Previously, the only way around this was to delete the working directory prior to running stateless, regardless of whether the working directory was incomplete, in which case the NAR must be unpacked each time stateless starts.  This change allows us to be confident that the working directory is complete, and thus remove the unnecessary working directory cleanup before each stateless startup.

While we could add some additional conditional code that only activates this mode in stateless, I don't think it has enough of a performance impact to warrant that complexity.
@exceptionfactory I think we're good to go now.

Thanks for the additional background @gresockj, that is helpful to know.  Would it make more sense to check the contents of the working directory and unpack as needed? It seems like this change could have a larger impact in some cases.

Thanks for updating @pgyori . I don't have any further concerns. @simonbence @exceptionfactory any concerns?

@markap14 I looked these through and they all look like good changes (which you probably don't need to be told). There's one thing I wanted to call out that I think might be relevant with changing the default to `${filename}`. I think it will break a quick creation of List -> Fetch without a user having to edit Fetch. The gist is that `azure.blobname` and `filename` aren't the same. The former includes the full path and the latter is just the basename (or it was that way).

See https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/3906#issuecomment-623016616
+1 LGTM, thanks for the fix! Merging to main

> Overall, great updates, @markap14! Using the processors felt much more internally consistent now.
> 
> I noted that while `ListAzureBlobStorage` does set the `filename` attribute, it doesn't set it to a value that can be directly used by `FetchAzureBlobStorage`. Instead, the `azure.blobname` contains what would be the usable value. For example, `filename` contained `test.txt` and `azure.blobname` contained `resources/test.txt` in my test, and it's the latter that is needed by `FetchAzureBlobStorage`. Additionally, `path` was set to `./`, which I think is not consistent. What do you think about setting `path` to the value before the filename, and defaulting the `FetchAzureBlobStorage` `Blob Name` property to `${path}/${filename}`? Not sure how this would work at the root level, however.
> 
> Same issue for the `*_12` processors. I have not exercised the ADLS processors yet.

Oops. Overlapping replies.

`${path}/${filename}` is not inconsistent with some of the other Fetch processors so I think it's a reasonable default. The behavior of `${path}` is also weird enough to call broken so it'd seem ok to change.
Awaiting further discussion on `TestConsumeTwitter` before making this PR ready for review. Have done all the required testing and checks.
@mattyb149 can we close this out or do you need more time to test with Hive and such?

Great catches @jfrazee and @gresockj . You are both indeed right - I did overlook the necessity of including the `path` attribute. Will update the Fetch processors to use `${path}/${filename}` and ensure that the List processors are properly populating the `path` attribute.

Thanks for catching that issue @thenatog! The problem is the result of having no Login Identity Providers configured, which makes sense when NiFi is deployed using Client Certificate authentication. It looks like the Factory Bean for the Login Identity Provider should retain the `Object` as the return type for the `getObject()` method in order to handle a `null` provider.

I've tested this with the single user provider and encrypted nifi.properties and flow.xml.gz, and with a 3 node secure cluster using X509. Also tested with LDAP which uses the LDAP login identity provider though the config was not encrypted. Also tested with Google OIDC (not sure if this would have been affected..)

I'll leave this open for now if we have further feedback from others.

Put this in the ticket; I'll also put it here.  Useful one-liner to test new module behavior:

```
export NIFI_CI_LOCALE="-Duser.language=ja -Duser.country=JP" && export SUREFIRE_OPTS="-Duser.language=ja -Duser.country=JP -Duser.region=JP -Duser.timezone=Asia/Tokyo" && export MAVEN_OPTS="-DargLine=\${env.SUREFIRE_OPTS}" && mvn clean install -pl :nifi-build
```
I can confirm that nifi now builds on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS with Java 8 and `LANG=C.UTF-8`.

Thanks @turcsanyip . That's a good catch. We can't really add the classes found in .class files because we don't know what the fully qualified class name is. We do know if it's found in a .jar or a .jmod file. Good news is that it doesn't really matter, as it's only used to detect classes that are part of Java itself, and Java packages all of their classes uses the appropriate packing mechanisms (.jmod / .jar) - at least in every case I've found. Hard to imagine that they wouldn't.

So I removed the .class from the list of things we add to the 'loadable files'. I think this is fine and addresses the mismatch between the two. I also rebased as there was a conflict with main.

Hi @esend7881 ,
Thanks for the PR, I'll take a look at it next week. In case of snmpv3 a USM (User-based Security Model) is associated with an snmp4j Snmp instance.
* GetSNMP queries information from an agent so it provides a single username/security name for authentication. This will be verified by the agent's SNMP engine (users must be set in the agent's configuration in case of v3)
* ListenTrapSNMP listens to SNMP Trap messages which can be received from several agents/snmp applications, so the USM can be defined in a json since you can add several users with different security settings.
Will review.
